'''''Tricholoma portentosum''''', commonly known as the '''charbonnier''',<ref name=BMS/> or '''sooty head''' in North America,<ref name="McKn"/> is a grey-[[pileus (mycology)|capped]] edible [[mushroom]] of the large genus ''[[Tricholoma]]''. It is found in woodlands in Europe and North America.

==Taxonomy==
The species was originally described as ''Agaricus portentosus'' by [[Elias Magnus Fries]] in 1821,<ref name=Fries1821/> before being placed in the genus ''[[Tricholoma]]'' by  [[Lucien Quélet]] in 1872.<ref name=Quelet1873/> At least three [[variety (botany)|varieties]] have been described: var. ''album'' has an all white cap, var. ''lugdunense'' has a paler cap, and var. ''boutevillei'' has a very dark cap and is the form which grows with oak and beech.<ref name=Nederlandica1999/>

==Description==
[[File:Tricholoma portentosum35.JPG|thumb|left]]
It is a large, imposing mushroom,<ref name="McKn"/> with a convex cap {{convert|3|–|11|cm|in|round=0.5|abbr=on}} in diameter with a [[umbo (mycology)|boss]].<ref name=Nederlandica1999/>  The cap is sticky when wet and has an irregularly lobed margin. It is dark grey in colour with darker grey to blackish streaks perpendicular to the margins. The grey colour fades towards the margins and may be tinged with yellow or purple. The crowded [[adnation|adnate]] gills are white, and the solid [[stipe (mycology)|stipe]] is white with a yellow tinge at the top. It measures {{convert|3.5|–|12|cm|in|abbr=on}} high and {{convert|1|–|3|cm|in|1|abbr=on}} wide.<ref name=Nederlandica1999/>  The [[spore print]] is white.<ref name=Phillips06/>

It has a [[farinaceous]] smell and taste.<ref name=Nederlandica1999/> Older specimens are often eaten by slugs, and the stem is recommended to be removed before cooking. It can be pickled.

==Habitat and distribution==
The fruit bodies appear in late autumn in coniferous woodland in Europe and North America.<ref name="McKn"/> [[Mycorrhiza#Ectomycorrhiza|Ectomycorrhizal]], it is most commonly associated with ''[[Pinus sylvestris]]'', but also sometimes oak (''[[Quercus]]'') or beech (''[[Beech|Fagus]]'') on sandy soils. It has been declining since the 1980s in the Netherlands and is now rare there,<ref name=Nederlandica1999/> and uncommon in Britain<ref name=Phillips06/> but is common in France where it is sometime seen in wild mushroom markets.<ref name=Lamaison2005/> It is common in Estonia.<ref name=Kalamees2010/>

Generally highly regarded as an [[edible mushroom]],<ref name=Mishra2005/> it is not recommended by some for its similarity to hazardous species.<ref name="McKn"/> The inedible ''[[Tricholoma virgatum]]'' has a silvery-grey cap and grows in mixed woodland, and smells of damp earth and has a bitter taste.<ref name=Nilper1977/> The poisonous ''[[Tricholoma pardinum]]'' has prominent grey scales giving the cap a shaggy or striped appearance.<ref name=Lamaison2005/>
